item.title: FileUtilities v1.2.3.9
item.description:
Product: FileUtilities v1.2.3.9
Company: LevyLab
Release Date: Tue, 30 Apr 2019 16:55:48 -0400
Packager: Patrick Irvin

Description: Utilities for working with files and folders

* DirExists-NoThenCreate.vi
* Checks if a directory exists, if not one is created
* Format number_123.vi
* takes a number and appends zeros to make 3 digits long (1 becomes 001, 25 becomes 025, 531 remains 531.)
* Format number_123456.vi
* takes a number and appends zeros to make 6 digits long (1 becomes 000001, 25 becomes 000025, 531 becomes 000531, etc)
* Format number_1234567890.vi
* same idea as previous but has a control for how many digits to add
* Ignore Hidden Files.vi
* Removes hidden files (.hidden) from an array of files names
* increment filename.vi
* If file.0.txt already exists change the path to file.1.txt, etc.

Release Notes: [1.2.3.9]
- update icons
- add LICENSE
- add README
item.dc:creator: LevyLab

item.title: lvarray2ibw v1.0.0.1
item.description:
Product: lvarray2ibw v1.0.0.1
Company: Andreas Wirsing
Release Date: Mon, 29 Apr 2019 11:54:57 -0400
Packager: Andreas Wirsing

Description: igorBinV5.llb

LabVIEW library to store arrays as Igor Binary Waves on disk.
Most of the features of IGOR Binary Waves are supported.
The waves are stored in IGOR Binary Wave file version 5 even if this is not required.
Because IGOR Binary Wave file version 5 was introduced in IGOR 3.0 the ibw files cannot be read with earlier versions of IGOR.

Restrictions:
The library was developed under LabVIEW 7.1 on a Windows 2000 machine. It will not run on LabVIEW versions below 7.1.
It is also successfully tested on a Win XP machine and LV 7.1.
It is neither known if Mac LV versions nor if LV version higher than 7.1 are supported.
Up to now it is not possible to read IGOR Binary Wave files into LV arrays.

Usage:
The library contains - among many other VIs - a VI called Array2ibw.vi. This is a Polymorphic VI, that chooses the the right sub VI depending on the data type that is connected to 'array in'. So only this VI is actually needed.
Copy the library to the user.lib directory inside the LabVIEW 7.1 directory to make the VI accessable via the User Libraries entry of the palletteMenu.

IMPORTANT: THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCE HOW DIMENSION INDECES ARE HANDLED IN IGOR AND LABVIEW!
IN LABVIEW THE HIGHEST DIMENSION IS STATED FIRST WHEREAS IN IGOR THE FIRST DIMENSION IS THE ROW DIMENSION.

Example: If you concatenate two 1-dimensional waves of the same length (and without the /NP flag) in IGOR you'll get an 2-dimensional wave. Using IGOR's DimSize function to reveal the dimension size you get for dimNumber 0 the number of points of the two original waves and for dimNumber 1 DimSize returns 2. Doing the same in LabVIEW with two 1-dimensional arrays and the Build Array VI and using the Array Size VI to reveal the dimension size, you get a 2 point array whose first entry is 2 and the second contains the number of points of the original arrays.
This VI considers this difference. An 2-dimensional array created via the Build Array VI as explained above can simply be connected to this VI, for arrays created via the Initialize Array VI for example, one has to pay particular attention on this difference. If not an IGOR binary file is created that does not reflect the data in the original LabVIEW array.

Thanks:
Gary W. Johnson for his great work on the first version of such a LabVIEW library several years ago.
_______________

If you find any bugs or have comments or feature requests, contact me or make a request on the IgorExchange site.

Andreas Wirsing, FU Berlin
awirsing@zedat.fu-berlin.de
Oktober 2010

Release Notes: initial build of _only_ lvarray2ibw.llb (was previously part of IBWtoLV package)
item.dc:creator: Andreas Wirsing
